title: 105_s1642
content:
The Act titled "Federal Financial Assistance Management Improvement Act of 1998" aims to streamline and simplify Federal financial assistance programs to improve service delivery. Congress recognizes the need to address duplicative and burdensome administrative requirements that hinder cost-effective service delivery at the local level. The Act aims to improve Federal financial assistance programs by enhancing effectiveness, simplifying application processes, improving service delivery, and promoting coordination among service providers. The Act defines key terms such as Director, Federal agency, Federal financial assistance, local government, non-Federal entity, and nonprofit organization. The Act defines key terms related to organizations operating for public interest, not for profit, and using proceeds for operational purposes. It also clarifies terms like State, tribal government, and uniform administrative rule. A generally applicable requirement established to achieve national policy objectives for multiple Federal financial assistance programs across agencies. SEC. 5. DUTIES OF FEDERAL AGENCIES. Each Federal agency must develop and implement a plan within 18 months of this Act's enactment. The plan should simplify application procedures, participate in interagency processes, use a common application system, designate a lead official, allow electronic applications, ensure timely reporting, and set annual goals. The Act requires Federal agencies to establish annual goals and objectives, measure performance, and publish plans for public comment. Noncompliant agencies may receive extensions for plan development and implementation. Public input on the plans is encouraged through various means, including public forums. Each Federal agency must hold public forums on the plan and consult with non-Federal entities during development. The agency must submit the plan to the Director and Congress, reporting annually on its implementation and performance in meeting specified goals. The report may be included in general management reports required by law. The Director is responsible for specific duties outlined in Section 6. The Director, in consultation with agency heads and representatives of non-Federal entities, shall direct, coordinate, and assist Federal agencies in establishing a common application and reporting system for Federal financial assistance programs. This includes a common application process, electronic management system, and uniform administrative rules across different agencies. The Director may designate a lead agency and use interagency working groups to streamline Federal financial assistance administrative procedures, improve coordination of information sharing, and enhance the quality of information received by agencies from recipients. Agencies must submit information to the Director for review upon request. The Director may exempt Federal agencies or financial assistance programs from the Act if they have few programs. Exempted agencies will be listed on OMB's website for public access. The Director will contract with the National Academy of Public Administration to evaluate the effectiveness of the Act, with input from various entities. The evaluation will assess the Act's effectiveness, agency performance, and coordination among different levels of government and organizations. SEC. 8. COLLECTION OF INFORMATION: The Act allows Federal agencies to gather necessary information for financial integrity reviews of activities receiving Federal assistance. 

SEC. 9. JUDICIAL REVIEW: No judicial review is permitted for compliance with the Act, and no rights or benefits can be enforced through administrative or judicial actions.

SEC. 10. STATUTORY REQUIREMENTS: The Act does not override statutory requirements for Federal financial assistance programs.

SEC. 11. EFFECTIVE DATE AND SUNSET: The Act will take effect upon enactment and expire five years later. Attest: GARY SISCO, Secretary.
